Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2011 08:30AM - edited Jun 29, 2011 08:33AM by Mantra I too had high grade DCIS in two quadrants of my breast. Also multifocal (8 tumors). I am also ER/PR negative. My surgeon told me that if cancer is all DCIS, then being ER/PR negative is not important. She said it only becomes an issue if the cancer is invasive. The oncologist agreed. I think if I had been ER/PR positive, I would have had tamoxifin but I honestly can't remember that part of the conversation. My lumpectomy was crossed over two quadrants. Given the number of tumors found, the grade of them and the ER/PR negative status, plus one small margin, my surgeon wasn't sure which route to go.The options were cutting more away or having a mastectomy. She was really hesitant to recommend a mastectomy in my case but put my case before the tumour board. All 10 board members agreed that a mastectomy was the route to go. I had a mastectomy and they found zero cancer. So in reality, I needed nothing more than the original lumpectomy. That said, I don't regret my decision and actually had a PMX 6 months later. I just couldn't handle worrying all the time. I didn't want to have radiation either. When I first met the surgeon I said "I want a mastectomy". Her attitude was that my decision was fear driven and she felt she could get it all with a lumpectomy. She said "we can always go back and do a mastectomy, but we can't undo one." She felt breast conserving surgery is what we strive for but sometimes a mastectomy is necessary. Where I live, they don't test pure DCIS for Her2 status so I'm not sure what mine would have been. It's normal to be scared sh$$tless!! I was a basketcase (to put it mildly). My daughter developed panic attacks as well although she has chosen to treat them without drugs. My grandchildren knew and they tried to learn everything they could about cancer. In fact, my 5 year old grandson was so devoted to helping people understand breast cancer he actually gave a speech to his school. He said it was the best speech ever (he's obviously anything but shy!). He said at least 50 people asked him questions and he knew all the answers. And he called the speech "my hero" and devoted it to me. He was also very moved by his teacher who hugged him with tears in her eyes and said she was incredibily proud of him. And like you, I had two dogs and was panicked that DH would not baby them like I did if something happened to me. Here I am, one month shy of my two year cancerversary. I recently went back and read my blog . . . OMG I was really a basketcase. I then spent the first year convinced every pimple, bug bite and pain was cancer. Now, I don't really think about it. The fear is never completely gone but I rarely think about it anymore. Take a breath. Learn what you can. And make informed choices. These boards were invaluable to me during my journey. Diagnosis: 7/10/2009, DCIS, <1cm, Stage 0, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER-/PR-

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 08:48PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:04AM by Mantra My sister had a biopsy and breast ultrasound. Her famly doctor told her that he couldn't see her for a month but would call if anything showed up on the report. I drove her crazy and kept forcing her to call the receptionist to at least ask if the results were in. She called once and the receptionist was beyond rude and told her that if something was wrong, they would call her. Another week passed and I told her to call the receptionist again. She said she didn't want to upset the receptionist. Three weeks later I was ready to drag her to the doctor just to see if the results were in. She finally agreed to call the hospital to check if the results were faxed to her doctor. They were apparently faxed within days of the biopsy. Again, I'm begging her to call the receptionist to tell her that the results must be lost because they should have had them two weeks ago. Again, she didn't was to upset the receptionist!!! When she went to see the doctor a month after the biopsy, the doctor said he never received the results. He called the hospital, had them faxed over and thankfully everything was negative. I on the otherhand get copies of absolutely any and everything. Blood tests, CD of ultrasounds . .  if it's a test . . . I have a copy of it. I also insist on getting my results regardless of whether they are fine or not. I want a phone call. This crap about no news means good news is ridiculous. It could mean the doctor never got the results, or she missed something. Calling and getting a copy forces them to relook at the results because they don't want legal issues if they fax you results that had something wrong and they overlooked it. Of course, everything has to be done sweetly and non threatening. Every doctor I have gone to has the same note posted "being rude to the Doctor or any member of the staff may result in you being dismissed as a patient." I do love our Canadian health care system but some of it is ridiculous. Do your family doctors have the "three issue rules?" It means if you have more than three problems, you can only discuss three of them and have to set up another appointment to discuss the fourth issue. I was on a wait list to get a GP in my town. In the meantime, I drove 1 hour to Toronto and 1 hour back to see my family doctor (I had moved away from Toronto). I remember I had 4 small issues to discuss (saved them up because of the distance). The doctor said "choose three and set up another appointment for the 4th." No way was I driving back for a sore wrist so I went to a walk in clinic in my town. The doctor freaked because he has to pay if you go to a walk in clinic. Too bad . . . my time is worth money and gas is expensive. So I'm getting my just desserts for you being an idiot . . . my family doctor for over 15 years! I never went back.

She then brought me out to see my daughters and said I could sit with my family instead of sitting in the waiting room. I guess having a crying patient sitting in the same room as people who were having that surgery that day was upsetting to others. Regardless, she handled it so well and my family said that she kept coming out to check on them throughout the day. Hats of to these wonderful volunteers! He said the presentation was amazing and that every single classmate asked him questions about breast cancer. He said no one ever asks questions after an oral presentation but everyone asked lots of questions after his. He said "not just a couple of kids . .. EVERYONE!! His teacher gave him top marks and said she was very proud of him and that his topic of choice was extremely important and that his knowledge was impressive. He is so involved in this and took part in the CIBC Run for the Cure. He made t-shirts for the run and even though he said the run was boring (well at least he's honest!!), he understood that it was extremely important to be there so he could raise money and support his grandma.   He is anything but shy and loves nothing more than having an audience and I hope he continues to share his interest with all who will listen. Posts.Content: Mantra wrote: A publication of the Lymphovenous Association of Ontario Weightlifting helps, not harms, breast cancer survivors with lymphedema The raditional advice from most health professionals for breast cancer survivors has been a long list of don'ts including exerting the arm at risk by heavy lifting or repetitive movements. An interesting new study published in the August 13, 2009 edition of theNew England Journal of Medicine highlights the benefits of weight-lifting for breast cancer patients and seems to contradict the common belief about lymphedema and exercise. Lifting weights, which boosts mood, muscle mass, bone strength and weight control, was thought to be a bad idea for women with lymphedema. That notion was challenged by a small study several years ago by Dr. Kathryn Schmitz, an exercise scientist at the University of Pennsylvania. She found that weight training did not make lymphedema worse. Her newest study is the first one large and long enough to give clear evidence that this is so, and even suggests weightlifting can help. The randomized, controlled trial followed 141 breast cancer survivors with stable lymphedema of the arm. Half of the women underwent twice -weekly, 90 minute exercise classes for 13 weeks, gradually building up their weightlifting resistance under supervision of a fitness instructor knowledgeable about lymphedema. They then undertook unsupervised exercise twice a week, for the next 39 weeks. The women wore custom fitted compression garments on their affected arm and their trainers made sure the weight lifting exercises were challenging but not too hard. The remaining women made no changes to their normal exercise level. After one year, only 14 percent of the weightlifters were found by their doctors to have flare-ups compared with 29 percent of the women in the comparison group (who did not do any weightlifting exercise). Arm measurements taken throughout the study showed that women in the weight lifting group weren't more likely than women in the comparison group to have their affected arm swell by 5% or more. In fact, the women in the weightlifting group reported greater improvement in their lymphedema symptoms - and of course, they got stronger too. The researchers said that a controlled weightlifting programme can boost strength in the affected limbs, helping to ward off injuries from everyday activities that can aggravate lymphedema symptoms. "Too many women have missed out on the health and fitness benefits that weight lifting provides, including building bone density", the authors said. "Our study shows that breast cancer survivors can safely participate in slowly progressive weight lifting and gain those benefits without any increase in their lymphedema symptoms", they added. The focus of this study was evaluating those that already had lymphedema; a different part of the study is already evaluating whether weight training can prevent a first case of lymphedema in breast cancer survivors. The authors are expecting the results soon. Although further research is needed, some cancer recovery experts suggest there are further cost savings implications to weightlifting, not only to reduce direct health care costs but also by potentially reducing the risk of disability by allowing women to return to work sooner at full capacity, either within or outside the home. However hopeful the news can be, breast cancer survivors are encouraged not to rush into weight training as that could trigger problems. Dr. Schmitz suggests: ● Have a certified fitness professional teach you properly ● Start slowly, with a programme that gradually progresses ● Wear a well-fitting compression garment during workouts.Compiled from various sources. The full study can be viewed at www.nejm.org Dx 7/10/2009, DCIS, <1cm, Stage 0, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER-/PR- Log in to post a reply

I had an aunt and first cancer with BC (both were over 50 when diagnosed). I told her I really didn't know anything more about my family but she said I had enough to qualify. The testing is done at Mount Sinai in Toronto and Orillia had the results back a lot soon that she had originally thought. I'd have to look up how long the results took . . . can't remember off hand.
